news_summary: Today's human rights progress highlights global efforts to protect civilians from harm, promote remembrance and justice, advance constructive international resolutions on conflict, and encourage governments to prioritize human rights diplomacy.
news_summary_fr: Les progrès réalisés aujourd'hui dans le domaine des droits de l'homme mettent en lumière les efforts déployés au niveau mondial pour protéger les civils, promouvoir la mémoire et la justice, faire progresser les résolutions internationales constructives sur les conflits et encourager les gouvernements à donner la priorité à la diplomatie des droits de l'homme.
news_summary_es: Los avances de hoy en materia de derechos humanos ponen de relieve los esfuerzos mundiales para proteger a los civiles de todo daño, promover el recuerdo y la justicia, avanzar en resoluciones internacionales constructivas sobre los conflictos y animar a los gobiernos a dar prioridad a la diplomacia de los derechos humanos.

Appendix: Political Declaration on Strengthening the Protection of Civilians from the Humanitarian Consequences Arising from the Use of Explosive Weapons in Populated Areas
The 37-page report, “Strengthening Civilian Protection: Principles for Implementing the Declaration on Explosive Weapons in Populated Areas,” introduces seven guiding principles to help countries that have endorsed the Political Declaration on the Use of Explosive Weapons in Populated Area put their commitments into practice. Explosive weapons also turn urban areas into rubble, destroy infrastructure, and damage the environment and cultural heritage.“Countries at war that use explosive weapons in populated areas kill, injure, and traumatize civilians, disrupt access to essential services, and cause mass displacement,” said Bonnie Docherty, senior arms adviser at Human Rights Watch; lecturer on law at the Harvard Human Rights Clinic; and lead author of the report. “The extensive harm recently documented in Ukraine, Gaza, Democratic Republic of Congo, and elsewhere shows that governments should intensify efforts to implement their expressed commitments to protect civilians from this method of warfare.”

The declaration, adopted in Dublin in 2022, is a nonbinding international instrument that seeks to prevent and remediate the devastating effects on civilians associated with using explosive weapons in cities, towns, and villages. Endorsing countries and other relevant stakeholders will meet in San José, Costa Rica, from November 18 to 20, 2025, for the declaration’s second international conference to encourage broader endorsement, review and strengthen implementation efforts, and outline next steps.The declaration says that countries that endorse it should take a variety of steps to better protect civilians, including “restricting or refraining from” the use of explosive weapons in populated areas and assisting victims of harm that has already occurred. Endorsing countries should also gather and publicly share data about the use and effects of explosive weapons that can be analyzed to learn lessons that improve civilian protection in the future.Human Rights Watch and the Harvard Human Rights Clinic urge governments to follow seven guiding principles to effectively implement the declaration’s commitments. These principles are applicable to all countries, no matter the structure of their government or size of their military.Countries that have endorsed the declaration should (1) comprehensively address the humanitarian consequences of the use of explosive weapons in populated areas, and (2) develop progressive civilian protection standards that go beyond existing international humanitarian law, Human Rights Watch and the Harvard Human Rights Clinic say in the report. Countries should also (3) collaborate with a wide range of actors; (4) ensure that all decisions are informed by relevant data; and (5) be transparent in implementation efforts. Finally, they should (6) internalize their commitments as part of their national laws and policies and (7) promote the declaration and its norms beyond the endorsing countries. “Strengthening Civilian Protection” builds on the 2022 report “Safeguarding Civilians: A Humanitarian Interpretation of the Political Declaration on the Use of Explosive Weapons in Populated Areas,” co-published by Human Rights Watch and the Harvard Human Rights Clinic, which focuses on interpreting the declaration’s provisions. Human Rights Watch is a co-founder of the International Network on Explosive Weapons (INEW), the coalition of civil society groups that helped drive creation of the declaration. The network and two civil society partners—Fundación para la paz y la democracia (Foundation for Peace and Democracy or FUNPADEM) and Seguridad Humana en América Latina y el Caribe (Latin American Human Security Network or SEHLAC)—will host a Protection Forum, open to all delegates, on the first day of the San José conference.“Governments that adopt strong measures based on shared principles can help maximize the declaration’s potential as a tool for protecting civilians,” Docherty said. “They can set standards that influence not only other countries that have endorsed the commitments, but also parties to armed conflict that have yet to do so.”
articles.content:
Click to expand Image Palestinians walk through the rubble of residential buildings destroyed by Israeli forces in Sheikh Radwan neighborhood in northern Gaza City, October 13, 2025. © 2025 Sipa via AP Images

Governments should act on recent political commitments to protect civilians from the bombing and shelling that devastates cities and towns around the world.

Civilians make up the vast majority of casualties caused by the use of explosive weapons—such as aerial bombs, rockets, missiles, and artillery and mortar projectiles—in populated areas.

Governments should maximize civilian protection in practice by adopting strong measures to implement their commitments. They should set humanitarian standards that influence not only other countries that have endorsed the commitments, but also parties to armed conflict that have yet to do so.

(San José, November 17, 2025) – Governments should act on recent political commitments to protect civilians from the bombing and shelling that devastates cities and towns around the world, Human Rights Watch said today in a report issued with Harvard Law School’s International Human Rights Clinic.

The 37-page report, “Strengthening Civilian Protection: Principles for Implementing the Declaration on Explosive Weapons in Populated Areas,” introduces seven guiding principles to help countries that have endorsed the Political Declaration on the Use of Explosive Weapons in Populated Area put their commitments into practice. Civilians make up the vast majority of casualties caused by the use of explosive weapons—such as aerial bombs, rockets, missiles, and artillery and mortar projectiles—in populated areas. Explosive weapons also turn urban areas into rubble, destroy infrastructure, and damage the environment and cultural heritage.

“Countries at war that use explosive weapons in populated areas kill, injure, and traumatize civilians, disrupt access to essential services, and cause mass displacement,” said Bonnie Docherty, senior arms adviser at Human Rights Watch; lecturer on law at the Harvard Human Rights Clinic; and lead author of the report. “The extensive harm recently documented in Ukraine, Gaza, Democratic Republic of Congo, and elsewhere shows that governments should intensify efforts to implement their expressed commitments to protect civilians from this method of warfare.”

Play Video

The declaration, adopted in Dublin in 2022, is a nonbinding international instrument that seeks to prevent and remediate the devastating effects on civilians associated with using explosive weapons in cities, towns, and villages. Endorsing countries and other relevant stakeholders will meet in San José, Costa Rica, from November 18 to 20, 2025, for the declaration’s second international conference to encourage broader endorsement, review and strengthen implementation efforts, and outline next steps.

The declaration says that countries that endorse it should take a variety of steps to better protect civilians, including “restricting or refraining from” the use of explosive weapons in populated areas and assisting victims of harm that has already occurred. Endorsing countries should also gather and publicly share data about the use and effects of explosive weapons that can be analyzed to learn lessons that improve civilian protection in the future.

Human Rights Watch and the Harvard Human Rights Clinic urge governments to follow seven guiding principles to effectively implement the declaration’s commitments. These principles are applicable to all countries, no matter the structure of their government or size of their military.

Countries that have endorsed the declaration should (1) comprehensively address the humanitarian consequences of the use of explosive weapons in populated areas, and (2) develop progressive civilian protection standards that go beyond existing international humanitarian law, Human Rights Watch and the Harvard Human Rights Clinic say in the report. Countries should also (3) collaborate with a wide range of actors; (4) ensure that all decisions are informed by relevant data; and (5) be transparent in implementation efforts. Finally, they should (6) internalize their commitments as part of their national laws and policies and (7) promote the declaration and its norms beyond the endorsing countries.

“Strengthening Civilian Protection” builds on the 2022 report “Safeguarding Civilians: A Humanitarian Interpretation of the Political Declaration on the Use of Explosive Weapons in Populated Areas,” co-published by Human Rights Watch and the Harvard Human Rights Clinic, which focuses on interpreting the declaration’s provisions.

Human Rights Watch is a co-founder of the International Network on Explosive Weapons (INEW), the coalition of civil society groups that helped drive creation of the declaration. The network and two civil society partners—Fundación para la paz y la democracia (Foundation for Peace and Democracy or FUNPADEM) and Seguridad Humana en América Latina y el Caribe (Latin American Human Security Network or SEHLAC)—will host a Protection Forum, open to all delegates, on the first day of the San José conference.

“Governments that adopt strong measures based on shared principles can help maximize the declaration’s potential as a tool for protecting civilians,” Docherty said. “They can set standards that influence not only other countries that have endorsed the commitments, but also parties to armed conflict that have yet to do so.”

articles.personality_title: New international steps aim to protect civilians from explosive weapons in war zones
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Explosive weapons like bombs, rockets, and artillery cause most injuries and deaths to civilians in cities and towns during wars. These weapons also destroy homes, roads, and important buildings, making life very hard for people living there.

**What happened** – On November 17, 2025, Human Rights Watch and Harvard Law School’s International Human Rights Clinic released a report urging governments to follow new political commitments to better protect civilians from these weapons. The report offers seven clear principles to help countries that agreed to the Political Declaration on the Use of Explosive Weapons in Populated Areas, a promise made in 2022 to reduce harm to civilians. From November 18 to 20, 2025, countries will meet in San José, Costa Rica, to discuss how to strengthen these efforts.

**Impact** – This is important because civilians make up most victims of explosive weapons in war. The declaration encourages countries to limit or avoid using these weapons in populated areas and to help those already harmed. The report’s principles ask governments to use data, be open about their actions, and include these protections in their laws. This can lead to safer cities during conflicts and reduce damage to communities and culture.

**What's next step** – The upcoming conference in Costa Rica will review progress and push for more countries to join the declaration. Governments will share information and plan stronger ways to protect civilians. Civil society groups will also join the talks to support these goals. Over time, these efforts could lead to new international rules that better shield people from explosive weapons.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Countries are working together with clear guidelines to reduce harm to civilians from explosive weapons in war-torn cities and towns worldwide.
articles.personality_title_fr: De nouvelles mesures internationales pour protéger les civils des armes explosives en zones de conflit
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les armes explosives comme les bombes, roquettes et l’artillerie causent la majorité des blessures et des morts parmi les civils dans les villes et villages en temps de guerre. Elles détruisent aussi les maisons, routes et bâtiments importants, rendant la vie très difficile pour les habitants.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Le 17 novembre 2025, Human Rights Watch et la Clinique internationale des droits humains de la faculté de droit de Harvard ont publié un rapport appelant les gouvernements à respecter de nouveaux engagements politiques pour mieux protéger les civils contre ces armes. Le rapport présente sept principes clairs pour aider les pays ayant signé la Déclaration politique sur l’utilisation des armes explosives en zones peuplées, promesse faite en 2022 pour réduire les dommages aux civils. Du 18 au 20 novembre 2025, une réunion se tiendra à San José, Costa Rica, pour discuter de l’amélioration de ces efforts.

**Impact** – Cela est important car les civils représentent la majorité des victimes des armes explosives en guerre. La déclaration encourage les pays à limiter ou éviter l’usage de ces armes dans les zones peuplées et à aider les personnes déjà blessées. Les principes du rapport demandent aux gouvernements d’utiliser des données, d’être transparents sur leurs actions, et d’intégrer ces protections dans leurs lois. Cela peut rendre les villes plus sûres pendant les conflits et réduire les dégâts sur les communautés et le patrimoine.

**Prochaine étape** – La conférence à Costa Rica examinera les progrès réalisés et encouragera davantage de pays à rejoindre la déclaration. Les gouvernements partageront des informations et planifieront des moyens plus forts pour protéger les civils. Des groupes de la société civile participeront aussi aux discussions pour soutenir ces objectifs. À terme, ces efforts pourraient mener à de nouvelles règles internationales protégeant mieux les populations des armes explosives.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Les pays travaillent ensemble avec des lignes directrices claires pour réduire les souffrances des civils causées par les armes explosives dans les villes et villages en guerre.
articles.personality_title_es: Nuevas medidas internacionales para proteger a civiles de armas explosivas en zonas de conflicto
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Las armas explosivas como bombas, cohetes y artillería causan la mayoría de las heridas y muertes entre civiles en ciudades y pueblos durante guerras. También destruyen casas, caminos y edificios importantes, dificultando mucho la vida de las personas que viven allí.

**Qué pasó** – El 17 de noviembre de 2025, Human Rights Watch y la Clínica Internacional de Derechos Humanos de la Facultad de Derecho de Harvard publicaron un informe que insta a los gobiernos a cumplir nuevos compromisos políticos para proteger mejor a los civiles de estas armas. El informe presenta siete principios claros para ayudar a los países que firmaron la Declaración Política sobre el Uso de Armas Explosivas en Áreas Pobladas, un acuerdo hecho en 2022 para reducir el daño a los civiles. Del 18 al 20 de noviembre de 2025, los países se reunirán en San José, Costa Rica, para discutir cómo fortalecer estos esfuerzos.

**Impacto** – Esto es importante porque los civiles son la mayoría de las víctimas de armas explosivas en la guerra. La declaración anima a los países a limitar o evitar el uso de estas armas en áreas pobladas y a ayudar a quienes ya han sido afectados. Los principios del informe piden a los gobiernos usar datos, ser transparentes sobre sus acciones e incluir estas protecciones en sus leyes. Esto puede hacer que las ciudades sean más seguras durante los conflictos y reducir daños a las comunidades y al patrimonio cultural.

**Próximo paso** – La próxima conferencia en Costa Rica revisará los avances y fomentará que más países se unan a la declaración. Los gobiernos compartirán información y planificarán formas más fuertes de proteger a los civiles. Grupos de la sociedad civil también participarán en las discusiones para apoyar estos objetivos. Con el tiempo, estos esfuerzos podrían llevar a nuevas reglas internacionales que protejan mejor a las personas de las armas explosivas.

**Resumen en una frase** – Los países trabajan juntos con pautas claras para reducir el daño a civiles causado por armas explosivas en ciudades y pueblos afectados por la guerra.

articles.title: Flower of Srebrenica takes root at the United Nations
articles.summary: A 12-year-old boy and his grandmother cut the ribbon at UN Headquarters on Monday to inaugurate a flower-shaped memorial to the victims of the Srebrenica genocide – a permanent reminder of the 1995 massacre and the United Nation’s failure to stop it.
articles.content:
“Our children were murdered just because they bore a different name, they were called differently, and they were Muslim,” said Munira Subašić, President of the Association of the Mothers of Srebrenica and Žepa, speaking to more than 100 people on a cold but sunny November afternoon in New York.

She has spent 30 years advocating for the more than 8,000 Bosniak Muslim men and boys killed in the UN-protected enclave of Srebrenica.

‘We are still here’

“This flower signifies that we are still here and there will be more of us,” Ms. Subašić said.

The marble flower has 11 white petals surrounding a green centre. The petals represent 11 July, the UN-designated International Day of Reflection and Commemoration of the 1995 Genocide in Srebrenica. White symbolizes the victims’ innocence; the green recalls the shroud placed on Muslims at death, and also new growth and hope.

Despite the horrors of 1995, Ms. Subašić said that the survivors “raised our children without vengeance, without hate” calling the children the new generation.

Representing the new generation was her 12-year-old grandson, Karim, who missed school in Bosnia and Herzegovina to attend today. He had lost his grandfather and granduncle, as well as 70 other family members in 1995.

UN Photo/Eskinder Debebe Participants attend the dedication of the "Flower of Srebrenica" Memorial honoring the victims of the 1995 genocide in Srebrenica.

Fight must continue

“I am proud of her,” Karim told UN News about his grandmother. “She is inspirational. I hope that she will continue to fight so no one will ever experience this again.”

He added that he and his friends don’t talk about what happened because they all have lost relatives and it is “too sad”.

Countering revisionist history

Speaking at the ceremony, UN Deputy Secretary-General Amina Mohammed said the new monument counters denial, distortion and revisionism history.

“Denial itself is an assault on humanity itself. It distorts history, dehumanizes its victims and deepens the divisions that make future atrocities possible,” she added.

The Special Adviser of the Secretary-General for the Prevention of Genocide, Chaloka Beyani, called the advocacy of Ms. Subašić and the thousands of other mothers “an act of love and remembrance to the victims” and a global commitment to preventing future genocides.

UN Photo/Eskinder Debebe Deputy Secretary-General Amina Mohammed with other participants at the dedication of the "Flower of Srebrenica" Memorial honoring the victims of the 1995 genocide in Srebrenica.

Srebrenica and Rwanda

The Flower of Srebrenica Memorial is a gift from Bosnia and Herzegovina to the UN Secretariat as part of the Srebrenica Genocide and the United Nations Outreach Programme.

It stands near another genocide memorial – the Kwibuka flame remembering the victims and survivors of the 1994 Genocide against the Tutsi in Rwanda.

“The monuments to the genocide committed in the heart of Europe and in the heart of Africa are witness to the truth, but also warn humanity to never again allow genocide to be repeated,” said Denis Bećirović, Member of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
articles.source: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

This has broad societal impact by fostering awareness and countering denial of genocide, with detailed context and meaningful symbolism.
articles.personality_title: Flower of Srebrenica memorial unveiled at the United Nations
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – In 1995, more than 8,000 Bosniak Muslim men and boys were killed in Srebrenica during a tragic genocide. The United Nations had failed to prevent this massacre. For many years, survivors and families have worked to remember the victims and educate the world.

**What happened** – On a November day at the United Nations Headquarters in New York, a new memorial called the Flower of Srebrenica was officially opened. A 12-year-old boy named Karim and his grandmother, Munira Subašić, who has spent 30 years advocating for victims’ families, cut the ribbon. The memorial is shaped like a flower with 11 white petals representing the date July 11, the International Day of Reflection on the genocide.

**Impact** – This memorial is important because it honors the victims and stands as a clear reminder of the tragedy. The flower’s colors symbolize innocence, mourning, and hope for the future. It also fights against people who deny or change the history of the genocide. The presence of Karim, a young survivor, shows how the new generation is committed to remembering without hate.

**What’s next step** – The Flower of Srebrenica will remain at the UN as a permanent symbol alongside other genocide memorials, like one for Rwanda. It encourages education and awareness to prevent future genocides. Survivors and advocates will continue their work to keep the memory alive and promote peace.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The Flower of Srebrenica memorial at the United Nations honors victims and strengthens global commitment to remember and prevent genocide.
articles.personality_title_fr: La fleur de Srebrenica inaugurée aux Nations Unies
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – En 1995, plus de 8 000 hommes et garçons bosniaques musulmans ont été tués lors du génocide de Srebrenica. Les Nations Unies n’ont pas réussi à empêcher ce massacre. Depuis, les survivants et leurs familles travaillent pour se souvenir des victimes et informer le monde.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – En novembre, un nouveau mémorial nommé la Fleur de Srebrenica a été inauguré au siège des Nations Unies à New York. Un garçon de 12 ans, Karim, et sa grand-mère, Munira Subašić, qui milite depuis 30 ans pour les familles des victimes, ont coupé le ruban. Le mémorial a la forme d’une fleur avec 11 pétales blancs représentant le 11 juillet, la Journée internationale de réflexion sur le génocide.

**Impact** – Ce mémorial est important car il honore les victimes et rappelle ce drame. Les couleurs de la fleur symbolisent l’innocence, le deuil et l’espoir. Il lutte aussi contre ceux qui nient ou déforment l’histoire du génocide. La présence de Karim montre que la nouvelle génération veut se souvenir sans haine.

**Prochaine étape** – La Fleur de Srebrenica restera aux Nations Unies comme symbole permanent, aux côtés d’autres mémoriaux comme celui du Rwanda. Elle encourage l’éducation et la conscience pour empêcher d’autres génocides. Les survivants et militants continueront à faire vivre la mémoire et à promouvoir la paix.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Le mémorial Fleur de Srebrenica aux Nations Unies honore les victimes et renforce l’engagement mondial à se souvenir et à prévenir le génocide.
articles.personality_title_es: La flor de Srebrenica inaugurada en las Naciones Unidas
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – En 1995, más de 8,000 hombres y niños bosniacos musulmanes fueron asesinados en Srebrenica durante un genocidio. Las Naciones Unidas no lograron evitar esta tragedia. Desde entonces, sobrevivientes y familiares han trabajado para recordar a las víctimas y educar al mundo.

**Qué pasó** – En noviembre, se inauguró en la sede de las Naciones Unidas en Nueva York un nuevo memorial llamado la Flor de Srebrenica. Un niño de 12 años llamado Karim y su abuela, Munira Subašić, quien ha luchado por 30 años en favor de las familias de las víctimas, cortaron la cinta. El memorial tiene forma de flor con 11 pétalos blancos que representan el 11 de julio, Día Internacional de Reflexión sobre el genocidio.

**Impacto** – Este memorial es importante porque honra a las víctimas y recuerda claramente la tragedia. Los colores de la flor simbolizan la inocencia, el duelo y la esperanza. También combate a quienes niegan o distorsionan la historia del genocidio. La presencia de Karim muestra que la nueva generación quiere recordar sin odio.

**Próximo paso** – La Flor de Srebrenica permanecerá en la ONU como un símbolo permanente junto a otros memoriales de genocidio, como el de Ruanda. Fomenta la educación y conciencia para evitar futuros genocidios. Los sobrevivientes y defensores seguirán trabajando para mantener viva la memoria y promover la paz.

**Resumen en una frase** – El memorial Flor de Srebrenica en las Naciones Unidas honra a las víctimas y fortalece el compromiso global de recordar y prevenir el genocidio.

articles.title: Security Council LIVE: US hails ‘historic and constructive resolution’ on Gaza
articles.summary: The Security Council has passed a US-backed resolution which will establish an international force to restore order in Gaza, protect civilians and open the way for large-scale aid and rebuilding. There were 13 votes for, none against – while Russia and China abstained amid concerns that Russia might veto the text. US ambassador Mike Waltz thanked ambassadors, hailing it as an “historic and constructive resolution” which charts a new course for the Middle East. articles.personality_title: UN Security Council approves international force to aid Gaza
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Gaza has faced ongoing conflict and damage, leaving many civilians in need of help and safety. The United Nations Security Council, a group of 15 countries responsible for maintaining peace, has been discussing ways to support the region.

**What happened** – On a recent vote, 13 members of the Security Council agreed to a resolution led by the United States. This resolution creates an international force that will work to restore order in Gaza, protect people living there, and allow large amounts of aid and rebuilding efforts to happen. Russia and China chose not to vote for or against, but they did not block the resolution.

**Impact** – This is an important step because it brings international support directly to Gaza, where many people have been suffering. The new force will help keep peace and make sure aid reaches those who need it most. This could improve safety and living conditions for many civilians.

**What's next step** – The international force will begin organizing its work in Gaza, coordinating with local groups and aid organizations. The success of this mission will depend on cooperation from all parties involved and the continued support of the Security Council members.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The UN Security Council’s new resolution sets up an international team to protect civilians and help rebuild Gaza after conflict.
articles.personality_title_fr: Le Conseil de sécurité de l’ONU approuve une force internationale pour aider Gaza
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Gaza a connu des conflits et des destructions, laissant de nombreux civils dans le besoin d’aide et de sécurité. Le Conseil de sécurité des Nations Unies, un groupe de 15 pays chargé de maintenir la paix, a discuté des moyens de soutenir la région.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Lors d’un récent vote, 13 membres du Conseil de sécurité ont accepté une résolution menée par les États-Unis. Cette résolution crée une force internationale qui travaillera à rétablir l’ordre à Gaza, protégera les habitants et permettra l’arrivée d’une aide importante ainsi que des efforts de reconstruction. La Russie et la Chine ont choisi de ne pas voter pour ou contre, mais n’ont pas bloqué la résolution.

**Impact** – C’est une étape importante car elle apporte un soutien international direct à Gaza, où de nombreuses personnes souffrent. Cette nouvelle force aidera à maintenir la paix et à s’assurer que l’aide parvienne à ceux qui en ont le plus besoin. Cela pourrait améliorer la sécurité et les conditions de vie de nombreux civils.

**Prochaine étape** – La force internationale commencera à organiser son travail à Gaza, en coordination avec les groupes locaux et les organisations d’aide. Le succès de cette mission dépendra de la coopération de toutes les parties concernées et du soutien continu des membres du Conseil de sécurité.

**Résumé en une phrase** – La nouvelle résolution du Conseil de sécurité de l’ONU crée une équipe internationale pour protéger les civils et aider à reconstruire Gaza après le conflit.
articles.personality_title_es: El Consejo de Seguridad de la ONU aprueba una fuerza internacional para ayudar a Gaza
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Gaza ha sufrido conflictos y daños, dejando a muchos civiles necesitados de ayuda y protección. El Consejo de Seguridad de las Naciones Unidas, un grupo de 15 países encargado de mantener la paz, ha estado discutiendo formas de apoyar la región.

**Qué pasó** – En una votación reciente, 13 miembros del Consejo de Seguridad aprobaron una resolución liderada por Estados Unidos. Esta resolución crea una fuerza internacional que trabajará para restaurar el orden en Gaza, proteger a las personas que viven allí y permitir la llegada de gran cantidad de ayuda y esfuerzos de reconstrucción. Rusia y China decidieron no votar ni a favor ni en contra, pero no bloquearon la resolución.

**Impacto** – Este es un paso importante porque lleva apoyo internacional directamente a Gaza, donde muchas personas sufren. La nueva fuerza ayudará a mantener la paz y asegurará que la ayuda llegue a quienes más la necesitan. Esto podría mejorar la seguridad y las condiciones de vida de muchos civiles.

**Próximo paso** – La fuerza internacional comenzará a organizar su trabajo en Gaza, coordinándose con grupos locales y organizaciones de ayuda. El éxito de esta misión dependerá de la cooperación de todas las partes involucradas y del apoyo continuo de los miembros del Consejo de Seguridad.

**Frase clave** – La nueva resolución del Consejo de Seguridad de la ONU crea un equipo internacional para proteger a los civiles y ayudar a reconstruir Gaza después del conflicto.

articles.title: Japan: New Government Should Adopt Human Rights Diplomacy
articles.summary:
Click to expand Image
          



  
        
  

        
                      
      
        
              Sanae Takaichi is applauded after being elected Japan's new prime minister by lawmakers in the lower house of the Diet on October 21, 2025, in Tokyo.
                    © 2025 Tomohiro Ohsumi/Getty Images
          
    


  
(Tokyo, November 18, 2025) – Japan’s new government should make the promotion of human rights central to its foreign policy, Human Rights Watch said in a letter to the new Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi on November 6, 2025. The Japanese government should affirm its commitment to human rights by taking the lead in promoting civilian democratic rule and the rule of law across Asia and around the world.Prime Minister Takaichi, Japan’s first female prime minister, took office on October 21. Japan, as the only Asian member of the Group of Seven (G7) advanced economies, has a significant role in promoting fundamental rights and freedoms abroad, including in Cambodia, China, Myanmar, and North Korea. Japan’s longstanding official policy “puts effort into improving the global human rights situation through bilateral dialogues, proactive participation in multilateral forums such as the UN, and constructive dialogues with the UN human rights mechanisms.”“Japan has long claimed to pursue human rights diplomacy, but it has yet to take meaningful steps needed to make that a reality,” said Kanae Doi, Japan director at Human Rights Watch. “Prime Minister Takaichi should swiftly enact necessary measures to promote rights-respecting governance crucial for the security and well-being of people throughout Asia and elsewhere.”The new Japanese government has the opportunity to adopt a number of important measures to promote human rights, Human Rights Watch said. The government should adopt a global Magnitsky-style sanctions law, which will allow Japan to impose targeted sanctions on serious human rights abusers abroad. Japan is currently the only G7 country without such a law. The government should introduce legally binding human rights and environmental due diligence for Japanese companies to address forced labor, child labor, sexual harassment, exposure to toxic substances, retaliation for organizing, and low wages in global value chains. In addition, the government should legislate import and export bans on goods produced through means involving forced labor and deforestation.The Japanese government should also show its support and commitment to international justice and the rule of law by acceding to the Genocide Convention. It should publicly express strong support for the International Criminal Court, including by denouncing and taking measures against US government sanctions on the court and providing the court with the resources it needs to carry out its work.Other priorities for Japanese human rights diplomacy include publicly denouncing cases of transnational repression by China and other governments; increasing assistance for refugees and other vulnerable groups; and establishing a program to support human rights defenders and open civic space abroad.The Japanese government should also take up key human rights issues in specific countries, particularly in Asia. It should press the Chinese government to end its growing repression, including crimes against humanity in Xinjiang, forced assimilation in Tibet, and the erasure of freedoms in Hong Kong. Japan should also continue to raise concerns with other governments about the Myanmar junta’s proposed elections; and press the Cambodian government to lift the severe restrictions on freedom of expression, the media, peaceful assembly, and association.“As Japan’s new leader, Prime Minister Takaichi has the power to transform Japan into a global leader on human rights, both at home and abroad,” Doi said. “Despite a turbulent geopolitical climate, Prime Minister Takaichi should embrace this opportunity to adopt new laws, policies, and practices that will allow Japan to reach its human rights potential.”
articles.content:
Click to expand Image Sanae Takaichi is applauded after being elected Japan's new prime minister by lawmakers in the lower house of the Diet on October 21, 2025, in Tokyo. © 2025 Tomohiro Ohsumi/Getty Images

(Tokyo, November 18, 2025) – Japan’s new government should make the promotion of human rights central to its foreign policy, Human Rights Watch said in a letter to the new Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi on November 6, 2025. The Japanese government should affirm its commitment to human rights by taking the lead in promoting civilian democratic rule and the rule of law across Asia and around the world.

Prime Minister Takaichi, Japan’s first female prime minister, took office on October 21. Japan, as the only Asian member of the Group of Seven (G7) advanced economies, has a significant role in promoting fundamental rights and freedoms abroad, including in Cambodia, China, Myanmar, and North Korea. Japan’s longstanding official policy “puts effort into improving the global human rights situation through bilateral dialogues, proactive participation in multilateral forums such as the UN, and constructive dialogues with the UN human rights mechanisms.”

“Japan has long claimed to pursue human rights diplomacy, but it has yet to take meaningful steps needed to make that a reality,” said Kanae Doi, Japan director at Human Rights Watch. “Prime Minister Takaichi should swiftly enact necessary measures to promote rights-respecting governance crucial for the security and well-being of people throughout Asia and elsewhere.”

The new Japanese government has the opportunity to adopt a number of important measures to promote human rights, Human Rights Watch said. The government should adopt a global Magnitsky-style sanctions law, which will allow Japan to impose targeted sanctions on serious human rights abusers abroad. Japan is currently the only G7 country without such a law.

The government should introduce legally binding human rights and environmental due diligence for Japanese companies to address forced labor, child labor, sexual harassment, exposure to toxic substances, retaliation for organizing, and low wages in global value chains. In addition, the government should legislate import and export bans on goods produced through means involving forced labor and deforestation.

The Japanese government should also show its support and commitment to international justice and the rule of law by acceding to the Genocide Convention. It should publicly express strong support for the International Criminal Court, including by denouncing and taking measures against US government sanctions on the court and providing the court with the resources it needs to carry out its work.

Other priorities for Japanese human rights diplomacy include publicly denouncing cases of transnational repression by China and other governments; increasing assistance for refugees and other vulnerable groups; and establishing a program to support human rights defenders and open civic space abroad.

The Japanese government should also take up key human rights issues in specific countries, particularly in Asia. It should press the Chinese government to end its growing repression, including crimes against humanity in Xinjiang, forced assimilation in Tibet, and the erasure of freedoms in Hong Kong. Japan should also continue to raise concerns with other governments about the Myanmar junta’s proposed elections; and press the Cambodian government to lift the severe restrictions on freedom of expression, the media, peaceful assembly, and association.

“As Japan’s new leader, Prime Minister Takaichi has the power to transform Japan into a global leader on human rights, both at home and abroad,” Doi said. “Despite a turbulent geopolitical climate, Prime Minister Takaichi should embrace this opportunity to adopt new laws, policies, and practices that will allow Japan to reach its human rights potential.”

This represents a meaningful potential positive impact on human rights, with broad significance given Japan's role in the G7 and Asia. The article provides detailed context on specific policy measures and targeted issues, indicating substantive content focused on advancing human rights.
articles.personality_title: Japan’s new prime minister urged to lead global human rights efforts
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Japan recently appointed Sanae Takaichi as its first female prime minister on October 21, 2025. As the only Asian member of the Group of Seven (G7) wealthy nations, Japan has an important role in supporting human rights across Asia and worldwide.

**What happened** – On November 6, 2025, Human Rights Watch sent a letter to Prime Minister Takaichi asking her government to make human rights a key part of its foreign policy. They suggested several actions, like passing new laws to punish serious human rights violations abroad and requiring Japanese companies to prevent forced labor and environmental harm in their supply chains.

**Impact** – This call is important because Japan is currently the only G7 country without a law to impose sanctions on human rights abusers. By adopting such measures, Japan could strengthen protections for people facing repression in countries like China, Myanmar, Cambodia, and North Korea. It could also support international justice by backing courts that hold criminals accountable.

**What's next step** – The Japanese government can now decide to introduce these new laws and policies. This includes adopting a Magnitsky-style sanctions law, joining the Genocide Convention, supporting the International Criminal Court, and increasing help for refugees and human rights defenders.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Japan’s new prime minister has a chance to make her country a strong voice for human rights in Asia and around the world by adopting concrete policies to protect freedoms and punish abuses.
articles.personality_title_fr: Le nouveau Premier ministre du Japon invité à diriger les efforts mondiaux en matière de droits humains
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Le Japon a récemment nommé Sanae Takaichi comme première femme Premier ministre le 21 octobre 2025. En tant que seul membre asiatique du Groupe des Sept (G7), le Japon joue un rôle important dans le soutien aux droits humains en Asie et dans le monde.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Le 6 novembre 2025, Human Rights Watch a adressé une lettre à la Première ministre Takaichi lui demandant de faire des droits humains une priorité dans sa politique étrangère. Plusieurs actions ont été suggérées, comme l’adoption de nouvelles lois pour punir les violations graves des droits humains à l’étranger et l’obligation pour les entreprises japonaises d’empêcher le travail forcé et les dommages environnementaux dans leurs chaînes d’approvisionnement.

**Impact** – Cette demande est importante car le Japon est actuellement le seul pays du G7 sans loi permettant de sanctionner les auteurs d’abus des droits humains. En adoptant ces mesures, le Japon pourrait renforcer la protection des personnes réprimées dans des pays comme la Chine, le Myanmar, le Cambodge et la Corée du Nord. Il pourrait aussi soutenir la justice internationale en appuyant les tribunaux qui jugent les criminels.

**Prochaine étape** – Le gouvernement japonais peut désormais décider d’introduire ces nouvelles lois et politiques. Cela inclut l’adoption d’une loi de sanctions de type Magnitsky, l’adhésion à la Convention sur le génocide, le soutien à la Cour pénale internationale, ainsi que l’augmentation de l’aide aux réfugiés et aux défenseurs des droits humains.

**Résumé en une phrase** – La nouvelle Première ministre du Japon a l’opportunité de faire de son pays une voix forte en faveur des droits humains en Asie et dans le monde grâce à des politiques concrètes pour protéger les libertés et punir les abus.
articles.personality_title_es: La nueva primera ministra de Japón instada a liderar los esfuerzos globales en derechos humanos
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Japón nombró recientemente a Sanae Takaichi como su primera mujer primera ministra el 21 de octubre de 2025. Como el único miembro asiático del Grupo de los Siete (G7), Japón tiene un papel importante en apoyar los derechos humanos en Asia y en todo el mundo.

**Qué pasó** – El 6 de noviembre de 2025, Human Rights Watch envió una carta a la primera ministra Takaichi pidiéndole que haga de los derechos humanos una parte central de su política exterior. Sugirieron varias acciones, como aprobar nuevas leyes para castigar graves violaciones de derechos humanos en el extranjero y exigir a las empresas japonesas que eviten el trabajo forzado y el daño ambiental en sus cadenas de suministro.

**Impacto** – Esta petición es importante porque Japón es actualmente el único país del G7 sin una ley que permita sancionar a los abusadores de derechos humanos. Al adoptar estas medidas, Japón podría fortalecer la protección de personas que sufren represión en países como China, Myanmar, Camboya y Corea del Norte. También podría apoyar la justicia internacional respaldando tribunales que responsabilizan a los criminales.

**Próximo paso** – El gobierno japonés ahora puede decidir introducir estas nuevas leyes y políticas. Esto incluye adoptar una ley de sanciones tipo Magnitsky, unirse a la Convención sobre el Genocidio, apoyar la Corte Penal Internacional y aumentar la ayuda a refugiados y defensores de derechos humanos.

**Frase clave** – La nueva primera ministra de Japón tiene la oportunidad de convertir a su país en una voz fuerte por los derechos humanos en Asia y en todo el mundo mediante políticas concretas para proteger libertades y castigar abusos.
